news politics tory-mp-branded-callous-claiming-"Katherine Fletcher says ‘we should help people sitting on benefits’ByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA Tory MP was branded callous for suggesting poverty-hit people are sitting on benefits and should get any job, as Britain braces for the biggest fall in living standards since the s. Katherine Fletcher was accused of an insult on struggling families after Rishi Sunakaposs mini-Budget last week failed to offer the poorest help for the looming cost-of-living crisis despite soaring energy bills and food prices.The Chancellor refused to reinstate the £ uplt to Universal Credit and, despite inflation set to average % this year, uprated benefits by a measly %, meaning low-income families will in fact be hit hardest.The Resolution Foundation, an independent think tank, calculated a staggering .m people, including , children, will be left facing absolute poverty this year as a result.But South Ribble MP Ms Fletcher sought to duck responsibility for the governmentaposs decisions when she appeared on BBC Politics North West.She attacked the Foundation, whose executive chairman is former Tory MP David Willetts, for not being fair or neutral, before outrageously suggesting people were sitting on benefits.  Weaposve got the same number of people unemployed at the moment as weaposve got same number of job vacancies, she said. The best way to help anyone out of relative or absolute poverty is to help them get a job. Told that even people in work were facing levels of poverty not seen in decades, Ms Fletcher replied no, no, and went on: You get any job, you get a better job, you get a career. She said the government was backing a plan for jobs, before adding: I went to see the job centre at Leyland the other day. Theyaposve got more vacancies than weaposve got job seekers. So thereaposs huge effort to put that in. People sitting on benefits - thataposs not helping them. Labouraposs Shadow Employment Minister Alison McGovern said Mr Sunak has failed to support the worst-hit families, adding: “For a Tory MP to suggest people are sitting around on benefits shows we’re being governed by the same old Tories. While working families are striving to make ends meet in the face of callous Conservative decisions that are making their lives harder, we have a Tory MP doing nothing more than insult them. This tired Tory Government is out of touch, out of ideas, and hopefully soon out of office. The Resolution Foundation found that a typical working-age household will see their real income fall % next year - a loss of £,, the Resolution Foundation think tank said.Absolute poverty - rather than relative poverty - is crucial because it is the measure Boris Johnson chooses to use.The Foundation warned the Tory Chancelloraposs £bn in cuts to National Insurance and fuel duty will also mostly benefit people in work.  Even with a p cut in income tax from , seven out of eight workers will still be paying more tax overall by , the expertsapos analysis found. “The scale and distribution of the cost of living squeeze, coupled with the lack of support for low-income families, means that a further . million people are set to fall into absolute poverty next year, including , children – the first time Britain has seen such a rise outside of recessions, the think tank said.It came as Mr Sunak was branded “Mr Tax” by shadow work and pensions secretary Jonathan Ashworth, as the Labour frontbencher warned pensioners have been “cutting back on hot meals” and “forgoing hot showers” as they cannot afford the cost.The Chancellor is reported to be considering proposals for a second council tax rebate to help ease the impact of soaring fuel bills, according to the Sunday Times, as even backbench Tories are piling the pressure on Mr Sunak to act. His package of support, which was announced before the mini-Budget, includes a £ up-front rebate on energy bills from October, which will be clawed back next year, plus a £ council tax rebate for homes in bands A to D from next month.Mr Ashworth told Sophy Ridge On Sunday on Sky News: “ Rishi Sunak absolutely had more room for manoeuvre in this spring statement and mini budget, but rather than acting in the interests of the British people, he was playing games.“He was acting in his own interest because he thinks by offering an income tax cut in two years that’ll help him politically with Conservative MPsthere’s a leadership contest or that’ll fit the Tory election grid.  “I don’t believe that putting . million people into poverty because you’re imposing a very severe real-terms cut to Universal Credit, you’re imposing the biggest cut to the pension in  years, is fair.” Mr Ashworth said Mr Sunak should have imposed a “windfall tax” on the profits of oil and gas companies to generate funds to help struggling families and pensioners with energy bills. He said: “He chose not to do that. “Instead, he’s imposed these very punishing tax rises, these very severe real-terms cuts to the pension and support like universal credit, and he’s expecting people to be grateful because two years down the road he’s saying there’s going to be an income tax cut even though that income tax cut nowhere near offsets the  tax rises that he has imposed on the British people, £, extra per householdyou do a rough and ready calculation. “He is a tax-rising Chancellor, he is Mr Tax and it’s the British people who are paying the price.”Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi hinted more help was on the way, when he said it would be irresponsible to say “job done” by Mr Sunak over the cost-of-living crisis.He told the same programme: “I think he will continue to keep an eye on this, it’s only right. “It’s irresponsible for me to say ‘job done’ because energy prices are volatile, inflation remains high, so it would be absolutely irresponsible to say ‘job done’. title: diy freckles tiktok beauty trend
story: DIY freckles TikTok beauty trend inspired by Meghan Markle leaves womens faces scarredBeauty experts have seen a rise in the number of people looking to copy the Duchess of Sussexs natural freckles, warning carrying out bodge jobs at home can cause scarringYoung women are attempting to copy Meghan Markles freckles by getting tattoos Image: WireImageByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Experts have issued warnings after a TiKTok beauty trend, believed to have been inspired by Meghan Markle ’s natural freckles, left young women disfigured. Several videos have been posted on the social media site of people injecting henna or black ink into their faces in an attempt to emulate the Duchess of Sussex.Several of the home jobs have left the young women in need of medical help as they triggered allergic reactions, with some facing permanent scarring on their faces. By using needles which may have not been sterilised they run the risk of catching the likes of HIV.The Mail Online reported Laura Kay, a London-based make-up artist, saying: “I wouldn’t advise that you get tattoo freckles done. “People who do tattoos at home without a licence are known as scratchers, and that’s not legal. “Tattoo artists must have a licence, and DIY tattoos pose a real risk of HIV or hepatitis.” Removal of the bodged “freckles” can end up costing people hundreds of pounds. Make-up specialist Sian Dellar, added most of those applying fake freckles were aged  to . She added: “There was a time when people wanted to hide their freckles, but now people really want them and it was Meghan Markle who sparked the demand. Earlier this month a woman was temporarily blinded in one eye from getting theaposfrecklesapos tattooedon her face. FormerBig BrotherAustralia starTilly Whitfeldtried to give herself faux-freckles with an at-home acupuncture treatment, using brown tattoo ink she bought fromeBay .However, she was left with severe burns due to the ink containing high levels of lead. The influencer has since spent more than £, to find a solution but is still left with permanent scarring across her cheeks.Showing her , TikTok followers the results of her laser removal for her bodged tatts,Whitfeld said: Itaposs fully bruised and there are blood blisters everywhere.Donapost tattoo your face, donapost do anything to your face.” Tilly later updated her post, explaining that she had scarring deep below the surface of her skin and dark pigmentation. She claried for those who thought it was just a rash, that it was anything but. I literally shoved needles deep into my skin, she admitted. title: dramatic pictures show uks anthrax
story: Dramatic pictures show UKs Anthrax Island go up in flames amid huge blazeGruinard island is known to many as  Anthrax Island and was contaminated during World War  when it became a testing site for biological weaponsGruinard island was consumed by a wildfire last nightByClaire GallowayGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Dramatic pictures have shown the UKaposs aposAnthrax Islandapos go up in flames amid a huge blaze. Gruinard Island was reduced to ashes after the fire took hold on Saturday night. People were astonished to witness the flames and smoke billowing into the atmosphere after the blaze took over the island in Wester Ross, Scotland.They took to social media to tell of the devastation which was seen from the Hebridean isles the Daily Record reports.One person saw the wrote: Gruinard Island ablaze, reports of seeing fire from Lewis. Another poster added: Very sad seeing Gruinard Island in flames but even sadder hearing the haunting screeching of the oyster catchers and geese.  The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said they were not aware of the wildfire until Sunday morning. And crews did not respond because there are no inhabitants on the island. The island in Wester Ross, known to many as aposAnthrax Islandapos, was contaminated during World War  after it became a testing site for biological weapons. Sheep were exposed to deadly bombs packed with anthrax on the island, which killed the livestock within days.  When inhaled, anthrax spores can damage the lungs and is often fatal. Direct contact with anthrax can also cause raised boil-like lesions on the skin. Gruinard was a no-go zone until it was declared safe by the UK Government in  following a major clean-up operation in . The British Army tested anthrax on the Island off the Scottish coast during World War II.  It led to spores of the infectious disease still being considered deadly decades later. Anthrax symptoms include fever, chills, and extreme fatigue, but the bodyaposs own defences can trigger deadly sepsis. The test was one of several Cold War incidents where animals were cruelly exposed to potentially genocidal weapons. title: i cant afford heat home
story: I cant afford to heat home and cost of sons favourite treat has more than doubledSingle mum Joanne Lao, , from Newport, is one of many residents in Wales who are expecting to be hit hardest by the worst cost of living crisis in two decadesCath Williams is one of many who are worried they will be struggling financially due to the cost of living crisis Image: John MyersBySean McPolin:,  Mar |commentsAs the cost of living of crisis begins to balloon, so do more and more stories of real people who will be hit hardest by the increasing prices. For many the crisis isnapost just about paying a few extra quid on council tax or energy costs, it will be wearing an extra jumper to avoid putting the heating on, on cutting back on your weekly shop.Joanne Lao, from Newport, has even made the decision to stop buying her nine-year-oldaposs son favourite cherry bakewells after they doubled in price, WalesOnline reports.She said: The ones we usually have from Asda are like p - we went in this week and they were £. for the same box.  Weaposve had to stop buying them now - itaposs just too much money. In recent months UK residents have seen rising costs from National Insurance, council tax, fuel prices and supermarket, with gas and electricity bills expected to increase in the coming month.And despite announcing a host of measures to tackle the cost of living on Wednesday, Chancellor Rishi Sunak hasnapost inspired many that he will be able to fix the problem.The people of Duffryn in Newport are ones who will be penny pinching even more now after previously admitting they would need to borrow money just to afford their heating bills. Single mum Joanne, , is one of many with a university degree, a reasonably well paid job and her own home who are nevertheless worried about creeping costs. She said I own my home but they own the heating, so I canapost flex to a dferent provider. Weaposre on a fixed rate, we canapost move to a better rate. I think in todayaposs climate there probably isnapost a better one anyway.  My electric has gone up probably about £ a month, incrementally. Iaposve noticed every couple of months I get a new letter saying my direct debit has increased. Food costs as well - my average food has gone from about £ a week to about £, and thereaposs only three of us in the house. Because Iaposm a single parent that works, Iaposm over the threshold for any help so Iaposve still got to pay for my childrenaposs school meals and things like that. But obviously Iaposm still on one wage and Iaposve got to pay my mortgage and everything. I feel Iaposm in a bit of a bad place with that. I think Iaposm kind of in the worst position. Sometimes I think Iaposd probably be better off not working at all, because Iaposd probably get help. Itaposs dficult. I am worried about it. Iaposve got nobody  to rely on for income - itaposs literally all on me. It makes me extra stressed in work, becauseanything happens to my job, thereaposs no backup. I have a good job, work full time, I went to university and got a masters. But it feels like itaposs still not enough. If Iaposm on a fair wage, over £-, a year, and Iaposm struggling to look after two children, I dread to think how people with a lower income can do that.  Iaposm not sure what can be done. Some sort of cap, maybe. It feels like itaposs spiralling out of control, everything. How supermarkets can get away with increasing everything so signicantly, is unbelievable really. Keith Bennett lives in Sandpiper Way in Duffryn with his partner. The -year-old says his costs have spiralled in recent months and are set to go up even more in April. I was paying £ a week for electric - thataposs gone up to £, he said. It was £ a year and theyaposve estimated it will be £, in April. My gas has gone up from £ to £. Then youaposve water on top of that.  My benefits wonapost cover it. Iaposve just got to try and work it out. My houses arenapost warm anyway, they lose the heat very quickly. They were built in . My thermometer is about  degrees in the winter - itaposs like a freeze box. Thereaposs the council tax rebate but youaposve got to go online and fill in [answer] questions. One of my friends stated he was on one benefit, and he couldnapost get it. Itaposs frightening - I canapost afford to eat sometimes. My children put £ onto my heating and say aposthere you go, have a bit more heatapos. Or theyaposll come around and cook me dinner and say things like aposweaposll get the meat dad, you just get the vegetablesapos. Thataposs what itaposs like. My family helps me a lot. My daughter is a nurse and sheaposs struggling. Her husband is too, and theyaposve got their own house and do as much overtime as they can. Keith said this weekaposs announcement by the chancellor would make little dference to older people and those struggling with their energy bills. He said: Itaposs not going to make no dference for the pensioners. Sure you can put the threshold up, but the income tax changes arenapost until . It might help the richer but on the lower end of the scale it wonapost help. Nan Cath Williams, , works in Asda but only does  hours per week due to health issues, meaning she has been struggling with finances recently.  I canapost work many hours because of my health. It is a struggle, she said. Itaposs been ongoing for a while. The heating is terrible - I put the heating on at  oaposclock in the morning for three or four hours. Thataposs all I can afford. Before I used to put it on in the morning for two or three hoursit was cold, and then in the evening. The electric has doubled. The heating, we had new systems one or two years ago. That made it soar. Before that, it was in with the rent. Itaposs all separate now. Shoppingaposs got to suffer. The prices in Asda have gone up, and itaposs not by  or p, you know - itaposs  or p. I buy unbranded things just to keep going. Iaposve got two boys, theyaposre grown up but they eat like horses. I havenapost got savings, I canapost save. Everything goes on the house. If you want to do DIY, youaposve got to save for a month just to get a tin of paint. Itaposs not always been like that. I am coping, but itaposs a struggle.  We need more help. We had the winter payment for the payment, but we put that in and itaposs gone already. Poll [council] tax, water, rent - itaposs all going up. I am on universal credit, butI do any overtime they just take it off me. So I either work all the hours and get none, or the other way around. Theyaposre supposed to be giving us money for council tax, but then theyaposre putting it up. The amount theyaposre giving us isnapost enough to go through the year. I am worried. Iaposve got a smart meter, and itaposs in my face all the time. I feel like hiding it. If I put on the kettle, I only put one cup of water in. I wonapost be able to retire until Iaposm . While ex-railway worker Dave Clark is also another pensioner worried about the increasing cost of living. The -year-old said: Iaposve just paid £ for three monthsapos electric, for the same amount that cost me £ before. Theyaposre saying itaposs going up again in a weekaposs time to about £ a year. Does it worry me  It does and it doesnapost -you havenapost got it you canapost pay them. When you get older, itaposs not nice to go into the debt. They could help with the VAT or something, I think. Iaposm on my own and Iaposve noticed costs going up, and thataposs not by a penny or two like it always does. A packet of frozen chips is going up by  or p. Itaposs terrible. title: life uk town families beg
story: Le in UK town where families have to beg for clothes and huddle in one room for warmthIn one of the UKs poorest towns those on the breadline have to make drastic choices to survive as the cost of living crisis hits, and say Rishi Sunaks Spring Statement does not go far enough.Across Greater Manchester, , people were on Universal Credit in February – .% of people aged  and over across the area Image: Manchester Evening NewsByPaige Oldfield:,  Mar |comments People living in one of the most deprived parts of the UK have to beg for clothes and huddle in one room for warmth as the cost of living crisis hits.Families are teetering on the edge and are regularly having to choose between starving and freezing as energy costs and food bills soar. They say Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement, with its p cut on fuel duty and National Insurance threshold increase, does not go far enough and the reality on the ground is stark.For people living in Oldham, Greater Manchester, where the number claiming Universal Credit has almost doubled in two years, day-to-day le is a struggle, reports the MEN. A trip to the town centre found a carer regularly surviving on one jacket potato a day, a pensioner whose food shop have soared from £ to £ and a mum who feels like a failure as she struggles to pay for school trips.Brits now face the biggest fall in income on record as inflation looks set to hit as much as %. In Oldham, a town with the second worst level of child poverty in the country, Julie Nuttall sits down clutching a polystyrene box. “This is our daily food,” she says, pointing down at her jacket potato. We might have a sandwich later, but this is our main meal.”It’s a hot March morning and the smell of baked potatoes fills the air. For Julie and her nephew Shaun, this food truck is a leline. It means they can afford to eat a proper meal today.“We’ve been walking aroundOldhamtrying to get the cheapest food we can,” the -year-old says. “We’re having child portions.”Like thousands of other families across Greater Manchester, Julie is facing the greatest uphill battle as the cost of living crisis cripples the country. A full-time carer for her disabled nephew, it’s a worry that keeps her up at night.“We do a lot of camping, we use an outside BBQ,” Julie, who lives in Hollins, said . “We’re going to have to make food on the BBQ just to cut back.“We’ve been given our bill for the next  months which has trebled in size. Weaposve switched the heating off now sowe get cold, we layer up. I know we have to pay and move on. But we have to cut back on usage and cut showers down. We have a disabled shower room which is going to make it dficult.  Weaposve had to cut back and prices are going back so we have to compensate somehow. Do you eat or heat  Thataposs the scenario. This time last year we were free. We could go into the community and come round here and not have to worry about what we had to eat. You go to bed and worry about what it will be like tomorrow. Barbara Szwandt stands outside a cafe with her daughter Janet. When asked about the cost of living crisis, a concerned look falls across her face.  The -year-old receives a pension but the money goes on rent and bills. Her financial situation once became so bleak, she was forced to beg people for warm clothes. Iaposve been struggling to get a coat and clothes,” she says. “Iaposve been going round askingpeople have clothes to spare. I donapost like begging and sometimes itaposs hard to do that. I had to get a coat instead of shopping. I have to ask my daughtershe has any shoes to spare.Barbara, who lives in Oldham, says she can only afford basic food including bread, milk and potatoes. Her total food shop used to come to around £. Now, she claims it costs around £. Itaposs hard when you get £ a fortnight on pension, then you have to pay rent,” she continues. It doesnapost go nowhere. Thereaposs nowhere for anyone to speak to anyone and see what help is available. Iaposve lost contact with younger age groups I have to rely on my daughter to do things for me. I canapost do a proper shop. “What I used to get cost me about £, now itaposs costing £. Itaposs basically just bread, milk and potatoes.”  Mum-of-four Janet Szwandt gently rocks her three-year-old in his pram. The -year-old cares for four children, including her autistic son TG. Money is so tight at the moment she can’t afford to pay for school trips – something that makes her feel like a “bad mum”. Itaposs horrible you feel like an emotional train wreck,” she says. “You get up and you donapost knowyouaposre going to have enough to survive the next week. Weaposve had to cut back on every day stuff like going to play centres. You canapost do anything because everything has gone up.  “Weaposve had to cut back on the monthly shop because we canapost afford to do it and it costs us a fortune. You have to budget what you need to spend to survive. Itaposs gone from £ a month to £. My daughter wants to go on school trips and I canapost afford to pay it. We canapost get the bus, we have to walk. Itaposs so silly we have to live like this. Itaposs even affecting the kids because they canapost understand why they canapost have essential things. They canapost have them because itaposs so dear. They canapost have pocket money. It just makes you feel bad as a mum because you canapost afford to give them what they want. You canapost make them happy. With UK inflation soaring to .% - its fastest rise in  years - millions of households will be worrying about their own finances. The  cost of living crisis is hitting energy prices, fuel and the cost of food, with the governmentaposs only solution so far to offer all households a £ loan to help pay off their energy bills - which must be paid back eventually. Chancellor Rishi Sunakaposs Spring Statement saw him announce a cut in fuel duty, although this will cost the Treasury billions without putting cash back in familiesapos pockets. So how will the Spring Statement affect you The  huge big cost of living blows hitting you from next Friday What the fuel duty cut actually means - and whether weaposll see the dference in our pockets The Spring Statement  summaryaposs key announcements Everything you need to know about the National Insurance cut The UKaposs current inflation rate amid the Spring Statement - as Brits are left with crippling costsKeep up with live announcements from the Statement in the Mirroraposs live blogIf you need help with the cost of living crisis, weaposve put together a list of charities and schemes offering advice and grants to keep you and your family warm and fed this year. Janet has also been forced to rely on food banks recently. I used food banks now and again and came off it because I was able to survive on monthly shops,” she added. “But Iaposve noticed the money I had left over, we donapost have anymore. We have nothing to fall back on anymore. Having a child with disability needs is so hard. Sometimes we put the heating on in one room and all sit in there. Even pensioners are struggling because I see how much my mum struggles as much as me. My son has never been out to a play centre and he’s autistic- I just can’t afford to do it. Terrance Ball, from Chadderton, claims Universal Credit due to being disabled. After paying his bills, he says he’s “lucky”he has £ leftover.Itaposs hard, itaposs very hard,” the -year-old says. “Iaposm having to rob Peter to pay Paul. Iaposm having to borrow money off friends. “Iaposm struggling Iaposm in financial dficulty I cannot afford and Iaposm a vulnerable adult. Iaposm having to cut back like on the essentials. Iaposm diabetic and insulin dependent. I canapost afford the food I need. I have to borrow off my friend. Itaposs really hard. Sometimes me and my we sit on the settee and we both cry.” Oldham currently has the highest proportion of the -plus population on Universal Credit in Greater Manchester, according to new figures. There are currently , people claiming the benefit in Oldham Town North, or %. Across Greater Manchester, , people were on Universal Credit in February – .% of people aged  and over across the area. The number has increased from , in February . The government donapost give a damn about us. Itaposs not fair. Iaposm not happy Iaposm content. But I would rather be happy, Terrance continued. We feel like weaposre just existing. We canapost go on a night out we canapost afford a holiday - not even for a few days. Weaposre having to look after ourselves and we have a little girl we need to look after. It feels like weaposre living in the s. I have PTSD and a lot of underlying illnesses I have to eat and I have to get my medication and itaposs hard to get them. After Iaposve paid my bills, Iaposm luckyIaposve got £ left over.  Michael Brown, also from Oldham, says he is “just about” coping with the dramatic price increases – although it is something that causes him stress. He said he’s noticed a rise in his fortnightly shop. My electric has gone up £ a month and my central heating works out at £,” he says. Iaposm just about coping with it. I call myself a stress head anyway, so I do worry about it. Itaposs going to get worse and worse. I used to spend £ on a fortnight worth of shopping in Iceland. “The last few times itaposs been £ for the exact same stuff. Itaposs p here and p there but it all adds up.  Mark Webster takes a break on a bench while the sun beats down on Oldham town centre. While he says his family is stable financially, he has found himself having to work overtime to keep it that way. “Itaposs a worry for me. A couple of weeks ago I got an email from my energy supplier. My bills are increasing by £, altogether, additional to what Iaposm paying. Itaposs incredulous,” the -year-old says. I knew it was coming, but I didnapost think it would be that large. I donapost think I can challenge it. Iaposm working overtime to pay for things. Luckily my we works as well, weaposre not as bad off as other people are. The only thing I can hope is that Labour get in next time. Weaposre frugal anyway, but I think what I am doing is working more to pay for things and having to work extra days to afford it. Iaposve got three children and one is going to university this year so we have that extra cost coming up. I worry about the cost of things over the next couple of years. I worry about how dficult itaposs going to be for them buying houses and I donapost know how theyaposre going to save up for a deposit. Thataposs why I encourage them to go to university and get a decent job. title: lotto pals who thought theyd
story: Lotto pals who thought theyd won £, sat in silence as they realised it was £MILLIONNorthampton duo Marion Wood, , and Michael Williams, , both scooped £, after their syndicated National Lottery ticket matched five numbers and a bonus ballNorthampton friends Marion Wood and Michael Williams were left speechless after winning £,, Image: Sam Bagnall SWNSBySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA pair of hopeful Lotto punters who thought theyaposd won £, sat in stunned silence as they realised their prize was in fact a whopping £MILLION. Syndicate PALS Marion Wood, , and Michael Williams, , from Northampton, were left speechless after matching five main numbers and a bonus ball on the National Lottery earlier this month.As NHS worker Marion read out the pairs numbers, Michael was in the kitchen checking the digits and even gave out a squeak when he realised how many theyaposd matched.Marion works at Northampton General Hospital and Michael is a retired construction worker - both will take home £, each.  Speaking about the le-changing draw, which left both in stunned silence and needing a cup of tea, Marion said: “I was on annual leave, it was the Tuesday after the Saturday draw which we won on. Michael and I always check our tickets for the last draw just before the next one. He was on his computer in the kitchen, I was in the lounge. “I started to shout out the numbers on my ticket and he shouted yes, then yes, then another yes and then his voice changed - in fact he squeaked! There was another yes and the final yes was followed by a ‘Can you come here please ’”  When Marion wandered into the kitchen and looked at the numbers on Michaelaposs screen she originally thought the amount theyaposd won was £,. She added: “I looked, looked again, Michael was going through the numbers one by one, and he kept on saying it’s a million, it’s a milli - and I said ‘I don’t know what a million in numbers looks like !’ Due to it being late on a Tuesday evening the pair had to excitedly wait until the following day to ring The National Lottery and make their claim.  “I’m a big tea drinker, so we had a cup of tea and sat in stunned silence as we absorbed what had just happened, Marion said. I didn’t tell a soul at first, I just carried on as normal holding onto the lucky ticket wherever I went. I kept the ticket in my diary, which I keep in my purse, until the lady from Camelot visited to check it and confirmed that Michael and I actually were big winners. “Even now it still hasn’t completely sunk in, but seeing our names on the big cheque has definitely made it feel more real.” Asked how they will celebrate she said, “I’m still unsure about what sort of celebration we’ll have but I am getting a taste for champagne having sipped a bit since the win. “Working through Covid in the NHS has been tough. The amount of work has increased and, unfortunately, I have lost many family and friends. However, work has kept me going, I love my job and I won’t be leaving even after this amazing win.”  When quizzed on what the pair will spend their winnings on Marion admitted she wants to carry on as normal for a bit, adding: I’m from an army family and routine is important to me so I think I’ll just let my head get around it first. I might treat myself to some jewellery, it will be nice to have something special to remember how I felt when I won.” While Michael, a father of three who retired last year, revealed heaposs going to spend his money on a his first car since  and some rugby memorabilia. He added: Finally, I’ll also treat my family, they’ve been good to me and it will be lovely to do something nice for them.” Marion, originally from Caerphilly, Wales, bought the winning ticket on Saturday, March  from her local Morrisons using number of friends and family memberaposs birthdays. title: mothers day date different every
story: Why is Mother’s Day date dferent in every country - and why does it change every yearIts Mothers Day in the UK today, Sunday March , and the clocks have also moved forward an hour, but ious countries around the world celebrate on dferent days during the year - heres whyHappy Mothers Day!ByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Mar |commentsHappy Motheraposs Day! Every year people around the world honour mothers and mother figures by sending cards and flowers, buying gts or simply showing appreciation for mums. In the UK the date of Mothering Sunday falls changes each year, but it always falls on a Sunday. This year it falls on Sunday, March , but this is dferent for ious countries around the world. For example, in Belarus, Bulgaria and Uzbekistan, Motheraposs Day fell earlier in the month, on March , meanwhile, Norway celebrates on on the second Sunday in February. So why does the date change every year, and why is it dferent from country to country   Why does Motheraposs Day date change every year   The reason the date of Motheraposs Day changes in the UK every year is because it has to do with Easter. Motheraposs Day falls on the fourth Sunday during Lent. The date changes because the date of Lent changes every year depending on the cycle ion the moon. That means that Easter Sunday can occur on any Sunday between March  and April , meaning Motheraposs Day changes with it. Why do we celebrate Motheraposs Day  Motheraposs Day is actually a Christian tradition stemming from the th century when Christians would visit their mother church on the fourth Sunday of Lent. Also known as Mothering Sunday, it has in recent years become more widely known as Motheraposs Day. Why is it on a dferent date in ious countries   Motheraposs Day is an international celebration and appreciation day of all mother figures. However, the date it actually falls on ies from country to country. In the US they launched a completely separate event in , devoted entirely to honouring their mothers. The holiday has no connection to religion, and is what the modern day Motheraposs Day celebration is based on. Anna Jarvis, dedicated community organiser and philanthropist, campaigned for a day in May to celebrate mums after her own died. The idea gained so much traction by  all US states observed the holiday. In  President Woodrow Wilson declared Mother’s Day a national holiday and a “public expression of love and reverence for the mothers of our country”. She later believed the day had become too focused on profit, and fought for it to become less commercialised. Anna said: “A printed card means nothing except you are too lazy to write to the woman who has done more for you than anyone in the world.” Many other countries have followed suit, deciding to celebrate on dferent days . For example, many celebrate on the second Sunday in May - including Finland, Greece, Iceland, India and Italy. title: mum who left concert soaked
story: Mum who left concert soaked in own blood forced to wait  years for diagnosisMum-of-four Linda Hardaker, , from West Derby, says doctors dismissed her concerns as heavy periods, but she was finally diagnosed with endometriosis after a decade-long waitMum-of-four Linda Hardaker had a full hysterectomy after suffering for years with pains and heavy periods Image: Liverpool ECHOBySean McPolin:,  Mar |commentsA woman who left a concert soaked in blood because of her heavy periods was denied a diagnosis for more than  years. Linda Hardaker, , knew she was suffering with the same condition her mum, aunt and cousins had been for years when she first went to the doctor about her mood swings and painful periods, aged just . But the mum-of-fouraposs concerns were constantly dismissed as a heavy periods, even when at  she was leaving a concert with her pants literally saturated with blood.The florist, from West Derby, finally received a diagnosis for endometriosis at , after being rushed to Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. She had collapsed and was in unbearable pain from a stabbing, twisting pain in her abdomen, the Liverpool Echo reports. Speaking about the problems around getting a diagnosis, Linda said: You start to doubt yourself. You start to think, aposIs this all in my head  Have I just got a really low pain threshold  Is this normal  Are these normal periods  Is this normal period pain  Am I just exaggerating  Am I just a wimp apos And obviously that affects your mental health. On average it takes seven years from the start of symptoms for people to be diagnosed with endometriosis. The incurable condition - which affection one in  women - sees tissue similar to the lining of the womb growing where in the body, as far away as someoneaposs lungs. It can cause debilitating pains during periods, when the lining sheds and the blood has nowhere to go like it would in the womb. Linda explained how the pains went away while she was on the contraceptive pill and during pregnancy, but came back with a vengeance.She added how she received le-changing treatment from Manou Kaur, a consultant at the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital, which gave her her le back. Manou gave Linda a full hysterectomy, removing her womb and cervix - using a robotic assisted surgery.  I felt amazing after my surgery, Linda said. Compared to my c-sections, where I was awake and felt groggy, this was so dferent. Following my recovery, I went swimming for the first time and found that I could stretch my body and elongate my torso. Everything felt so stuck together before. Iaposm still finding new things I wasnapost able to do before the surgery. I feel so lucky. Itaposs made such a dference to the family. The Derby mum also diagnosed with premenstrual dysphoric disorder , which had left her anxious and unable to cope at times. Linda explained she was dumbfounded that it took until she was  for this to be diagnosed. She said: My struggles with my mental health and PMDD symptoms completely coincided with my cycle, and now itaposs lted.I wish I recognised it sooner and went on medication, because I feel like I missed out on opportunities with being either riddled with anxietyor feeling sad.At points, I turned up to the doctors sobbing and received depression medication. Nobody told me it could coincide with my cycle. title: my boyfriend 10 years younger
story: My boyfriend was  years younger, charming and funny - then he almost killed meAfter eventually escaping the abusive relationship, mum-of-two Emma Cranston has since retrained in psychotherapy and formed a friendship with TV therapist Robert HiseeEmma, , was attacked by her ex-partner Arathoon in February  Image: Focus FeaturesByAnn CusackSaffron Otter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA mum who was beaten so badly by her abusive partner that she had to be airlted to hospital has joined forces with a celebrity therapist to help other victims of domestic abuse. Emma Cranston was savagely attacked by former partner George Arathoon, who forbade her to wear make-up, forced her to give up her job and manipulated her into thinking she couldnapost live without him. After eventually escaping the relationship, the mum-of-two has since retrained in psychotherapy and formed a friendship with TV therapist Robert Hisee. Emma, , was attacked by her ex-partner Arathoon in February . He was later handed a five-year prison sentence for the assault.Emma told the Manchester Evening News that she met George when he moved into her street in Cheshire in .“George was  years younger than me, but we became pals and it went from there. He was very charming and funny, and I felt I could tell him anything, Emma said. In  they moved in together, but the relationship quickly became volatile and violent. “Each time he managed to convince me it was my fault, he told me I was as bad as him, she said. “I started to think it was wrong to stand up for myself and I began to think I couldn’t live without him. I didn’t see my friends. I didn’t go anywhere without George. “I wasn’t allowed to wear make-up or fake tan or dress up nicely, and in the end, I just gave up. I suppose the fight just went out of me. It was easier to do as I was told.  “I had a good job in a call centre but he made me leave because there were other men there. I was living in a constant state of fear.” In February , George launched an attack that almost killed her. Emma explained: “We had been out for the evening, and I was driving us home. I turned the music up in the car and that was enough to make George flip.” George inflicted injuries so severe that Emma was air-lted to hospital. She suffered multiple broken ribs, and a punctured lung which resulted in blood collecting in between her chest wall and her lung. Doctors also found old healing fractures from earlier attacks. They told Emma she was at risk of a heart attack and was lucky to be alive. She needed surgery to fit metal plates and pins into her back and ribs and had three ribs completely rebuilt. But, despite her ordeal, Emma admits she still had reservations about speaking to the police.  On Valentine’s Day , she finally plucked up the courage to seek justice. George Arathoon was convicted in July  of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, inflicting grievous bodily harm and intimidation. He was jailed for five years at Chester Crown Court. A restraining order was also put in place to stop him from contacting Emma or her family. Emma has since thrown herself into helping other women, setting up a support group, ‘Love Doesn’t Hurt’, which reaches across the globe, with over half a million followers. And earlier this month, she teamed up with Robert Hisee, who will offer his therapies via the support group. Robert, ‘The Hypnotist Man,’ has worked with celebrities like Lauren Goodger, Dame Kelly Holmes, Tom Zanetti, Paul Gascoigne and Gemma Collins, using his own Unconscious Mind Therapy.Emma and Robert, , say they have the support of MPs and hope to be granted charitable status soon. Emma said: “I am so excited to be working with Robert, I have huge admiration for him. I signed up for one of his courses and I have never looked back. So many women I meet have psychological and physical damage and our programme focuses on recovery.” ‘Love Doesn’t Hurt’ offers abuse and trauma recovery using aposunconscious mind therapyapos which promises to help transform thoughts, feelings, emotions , habits and beliefs to help people get over domestic and emotional abuse. Robert said: “We want to create an environment where it is safe to talk and heal – and where they can all help each other too. People need that sort of encouragement and support. It’s about recovery and moving forwards. This is a place for traumatised people to access my expertise in a safe place.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Paul GascoigneKelly HolmesLauren GoodgerHospitalsLoveCourt caseCrown courtFake tanHeart attackHeart diseaseDomestic violenceTherapyHypnotism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: over 600000 brits invited spring
story: Over , Brits invited for spring booster jab next week - priority list revealedMore than , Brits will be invited for a booster jab next week as Covid- infection levels climb to record highs across England.In total . million people will be invited for a new booster in the coming months Image: PAByEd McConnell:,  Mar |comments More than , will be invited for a booster jab next week as Covid- infections levels climb to record highs in England.Around . million people in England aged over  or immunosuppressed will become eligible in the coming months. Cases have risen for a third week in a row with one in  estimated to have had Covid in the week to March , according to Office for National Statistics data. Thataposs . million people, up from .mthe previous week, a rise of almost a third. Spring boosters were rolled out last week and so far more than , people have come forward.Will you get your booster  Have your say in the comment sectionThe NHS wants people to wait until they are invited before trying to book, with the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation saying a six-month gap after the initial booster is best for maximum effectiveness. A more transmissible iant of Omicron, known as Omicron BA., is behind a surge in infections, with the percentage of people testing positive up across all age groups and regions of England.Infection levels in over-s are at their highest since the pandemic began, with around one in  likely to have the virus, up week-on-week from one in .But Covid- remains most prevalent among young children, with around one in  of those aged between two and school year  estimated to have had coronavirus last week, up from one in . The number of people in hospital with the virus continues to increase, although at a slower rate. Dr Nikki Kanani, deputy lead for the NHS Vaccination Programme, said: Over the course of the pandemic vaccinations have been key to helping society get back to normal and allowing us to enjoy time with friends, family and loved ones - and they continue to play a crucial role in protecting us all against Covid, so please do book in when invited.Health and Social Care Secretary Sajid Javid said: Iaposm so grateful to our brilliant NHS staff and volunteers who have sprung into action yet again to rollout Spring boosters to keep the most vulnerable safe.Vaccines remain our best line of defence against this virus, and itaposs thanks to these protections that we are all able to do the things we love. With hundreds of thousands more invites being sent to eligible people this week, itaposs vital to come forward as soon as you can. Free tests are set to be ditched on April  but the climbing case numbers have led many advisors to urge the government to reconsider and to urge people to wear masks again. Earlier this week, SAGE member Professor Matt Keeling said: With the withdrawal of free testing from April , this ability of the public to assess and respond to the risk of infection has been removed. Lateral flow tests are relatively inexpensive, and could even be cost savingthey help prevent sufficiently many hospital admissions. Meanwhile, chief medical adviser at the UK Health Security Agency Dr Susan Hopkins asked Britons to wear masks in enclosed spaces and socialise outdoors. Yesterday, daily cases fell week-on-week to , but the number of people in hospital climbed to , while  people died. news uk-news princess-charlottes-poignant-mothers-day-"GEORGE, CHARLOTTE AND LOUIS WRITE MOTHERS DAY CARDS TO DIANA - PAPA IS MISSING YOUByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsNow their royal tour of the Caribbean is over, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will be eager to spend time with their children George, Charlotte and Louis. And today will be extra special for Kate as it is Motheraposs Day and no doubt her little ones have some lovely surprises for her when she arrives home. Itaposs also a day when Kate will honour her mum Carole Middleton, and the whole family will also remember Prince Williamaposs late mother Princess Diana. Even though she did not get to meet her grandchildren, William has spoken in the past of how he talks to his children about their granny.And last Motheraposs Day, the youngsters all created cards for Diana - with Princess Charlotteaposs containing a particularly poignant message. Her message was on a fuchsia coloured card with a hand-drawn multi-coloured heart. And in it, she made sure to mention how much her dad William misses his mum. Charlotte wrote: Dear Granny Diana, I am thinking of you on motheraposs day. I love you very much. Papa is missing you. Lots of love Charlotte xxxxxxxxx.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . Meanwhile, older brother George used joined-up writing on bright green card to say: Dear granny Diana, Happy happy Motheraposs Day. I love you very much and think of you always, sending lots of love from George xxxxx.And Louis, who was just two at the time, also used green card for his Motheraposs Day card which featured a colourful heart surrounded by several animals - all of which had been stuck on to the card.The cards were posted on the official Twitter account for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge where four images were uploaded, with a heartfelt message. It revealed: Each year on Mother’s Day, George, Charlotte and Louis make cards remembering their Granny, Diana, for William. Whatever your circumstances, we are thinking of you this Mother’s Day. In the  documentary Diana, Our Mother: Her Le and Legacy, William spoke openly saying he is committed to making sure his children know all about their late grandmother. He said wants his kids to “know who she was and that she existed” and told how he “constantly” talks to his children “about Granny Diana” at bedtime so that they know “there are two grandmothers in their lives”. The future king said: “We’ve got more photos up around the house now of her and we talk about her a bit.” He added: “It’s hard because obviously Catherine didn’t know her so she cannot really provide that level of detail, so I regularly put George and Charlotte to bed, talk about her and just try to remind them that there are two grandmothers, there were two grandmothers in their lives. “So it’s important that they know who she was and that she existed.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mothers DayKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgePrincess CharlottePrincess DianaPrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queens-speech-state-opening-parliament-"Queen Elizabeth speaks at State Opening of Parliament in ByEd McConnell:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsPrince Charles is on stand-by to fill in for the Queen at the State Opening of Parliamentshe is too unwell to attend, it is reported. Plans have been drawn up which would see him read his mumaposs Speech on her behalf.It comes as the Prince of Wales takes on an increasing amount of duties from his -year-old mother, The Sun reports. The ceremony takes place on Tuesday, May , with the speech setting out the Government’s agenda for the next session. It will reference plans to grow the economy, cut the cost of living, make streets safer and clear the Covid backlogs.  A statement on the governmentaposs website says: The Queen’s Speech will provide the leadership needed in challenging times to level up opportunities and employment in all parts of the United Kingdom. The current session of Parliament will be prorogued ahead of the speech so security preparations can be made. The likely date of prorogation is yet to be confirmed.  Elizabeth II has only missed it twice in her  years on the throne, when she was pregnant with Andrew and Edward in  and . The Queen will confirm her attendance on the day, with the plan being drawn up amid issues with her general health and mobility.Last month, she caught Covid- but only experienced mild symptoms and continued some light duties at Windsor.  Before then, in her first public appearance since Andrew settled his sex abuse case, she alarmed Royal observers by telling Defence Services Secretary Major General Eldon Millar and his predecessor Rear Admiral James Macleod as you can see, I canapost move, while holding a walking stick and pointing to her leg or foot in a meeting at the castle.Earlier this month it emerged she plans to spend more time at Craigowan Lodge, on her Balmoral Estate, which has had a £, wheelchair-friendly lt fitted.But this week, her unofficial biographer Robert Hardman said she was in “very good spirits” after reports she was now largely confined to using a wheelchair.Get all the royal news and gossip you want straight to your inbox.toone of the Mirroraposs newslettersHe said: “Mobility is something of an issue now…I’m told by those very close to her that sheaposs in very good spirits, you know - absolutely pin-sharp as ever. “But there is a mobility issue inevitably when youaposre coming up to your th birthday and also dignity, I think itaposs terribly important.And last year she spent a night in hospital for precautionary checks after cancelling a planned trip to Northern Ireland. Since then, she has carried out a number of duties virtually or been replaced at events by -year-old Charles, who was also struck down with Covid a week or so before The Queen caught it. The Queenaposs jubilee will be marked with a four-day bank holiday from Thursday, June . title: schools open least 32 hours
story: All schools ordered to open for at least . hours a week so kids dont miss outMinisters say they want to abolish discrepancies in school opening hours, with around % of schools in England currently open for fewer than  hours per weekSchools will have to open for at least . hours a week under new plans Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsAll schools must open for at least . hours a week under new Government plans. Although the vast majority of schools in England already pass this threshold, around % are open for fewer than  hours per week. Ministers say they want to abolish discrepancies in school opening hours, which are currently decided by headteachers, by . The Government said the change, which starts next September, will ensure children have access to a range of subjects and catch-up support.The new .-hour week is equivalent to an .am to .pm day from Monday to Friday. Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said a child who receives  minutes less teaching per day loses out on two weeks of lessons per year.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He told Sky News: “The average school day is -and-a-half hours. Some schools, thousands of schools are  minutes lower than that – so we want schools to be, sort of, am to .pm. “I’d like them all to do it by the end of this year, but I know some will have logistical problems. Which is why we’ve said by next year.” The minister told the BBC the Government would set out its plans for schools in England in the coming week, with a focus on strong multi-academy trusts.He added The evidence is clear that a family of schools that is really tightly managed, really well supported - especially through Covid - has delivered better educational outcomes for children. So strong - and I underline strong - multi-academy trusts is the infrastructure we need to complete and deliver. However, unions claim the change to school hours will make little impact on students and could even have a negative effect. Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: We are unconvinced by the benefits of introducing a minimum expectation on theof the school week of . hours.Adding time on to the school week may sound straightforward, but there are many issues which need to be considered in inidual schools, and we would encourage the government not to rush any changes. Paul Whiteman, of the headteachersapos union the NAHT, said: We hope that during the year before these proposals are implemented, there can be a review of the evidence supporting this plan. Simply adding five or  minutes to a day is unlikely to bring much,any, benefit. The government says it will be guided by evidence - they need to meet that undertaking.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: three bedroom house could yours
story: Three-bedroom house could be yours for just £, – but its absolutely filthy insidePhotos on the listing, which is set to go to auction on March , show that each room is incredibly run-down with piles of rubbish strewn all over the placeThe home is set to go to auction on March  Image: Allsop Auctions Daily Post WalesByAaran Lennox:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA three-bedroom home is up for auction for just £, - but images showing the home’s state of disrepair have attracted attention for all the wrong reasons.The home in Llandudno, Wales, which is currently expected to sell for just £,, is in need of some major TLC, North Wales Live reports. Photos on the listing, which is set to go to auction on March , show that each room is incredibly run-down, with piles of rubbish strewn all over the place. One room shows a pack of Stella Artois on the bedside cabinet which,youaposre lucky, could end up coming with the auctioned property.  The house listing has been shared on social media with a lot of people commenting on its condition. However, estate agents Allsop has reassured potential buyers that the house will be cleared of all rubbish and unwanted items when the sale of the site is completed. With a large overgrown rear garden, the property is situated on the north west side of Maesdu Road, to the south west of its junction with Ffordd Las.  It comes complete with three bedrooms, one bathroom, two reception rooms and a very cluttered kitchen. Clutter inside shows stacks of paper piled up in one corner of the room, a dirty unmade bed and a mould-ridden toilet along with rubbish and bags strewn over the rear overgrown garden floor. Whoever takes on the property will need some serious elbow grease - and a strong stomach.  Allsop auctions say the property will be open for viewing every Monday and Wednesday before the auction. However, the company strongly encourages that all viewers wear a face mask and gloves when viewing the property.They also ask people not to visitthey are displaying symptoms of coronavirus.The three bed end terrace house is located overlooking the large Llandudno Rugby Field and stands only minutes away from the A.  This gives direct links to the A expressway and has an extensive range of local shops and amenities are available within the coastal town of Llandudno. Most of the similar sales in surrounding areas have sold with the average price of £, over the last year. news uk-news touching-way-kate-middleton-paid-"Kate Middleton and Prince William visit BelizeByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsOver the last week, Prince William and Kate Middleton have been on their first joint overseas tour since , heading to the Caribbean to visit Jamaica, The Bahamas and Belize to celebrate the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee.Throughout the tour, the Duchess of Cambridge sported some truly stunning looks, including a sparkly hot pink number by The Vampireaposs We. But it wasnapost the only colourful outfit the -year-old wore during the week, with her wardrobe including lots of bright, bold hues - including yellow, blue, green and orange.Following the tour, a stylist has claimed that Kateaposs colourful outfits might have been a nod to the Queenaposs own wardrobe ethos and praised her for the touching tribute.  Speaking to Femail, Hannah Eichler said: Whether itaposs orange for optimism, blue for confidence, red for love or yellow for warmth, Kate has followed the Queenaposs cue by using colour to invoke powerful feelings of energy amongst herself and her subjects - a key tool when visiting new countries and engaging with those around her. Bright colours have long been favoured by the Royal family but no one has championed the look more so than the Queen herself.As a lover of colour herself, the Duchess has paid homage to the Queen during her tour this week, and while these colourful looks will no doubt get the royal nod of approval, they also make a statement about Kateaposs emotions, too.The Queen is known for having a wardrobe boasting all the colours of the rainbow and is thought to dress to invoke powerful feelings and energy. However, there is one big dference between the way the monarch and the Duchess of Cambridge dress in bright colours. Her Majesty will often pair a matching colourful accessory with her outfits - this is most commonly a hat.  She is also known to have an umbrella to match all of her colourful coats for wet weather, should she need one.But Hannah thinks that by forgoing colourful hats, Kate seems more modern and relaxed - do you agree  Let us know in the comments below.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. news uk-news uk-weather-exact-date-cold-"UK Weather: Met Office forecast temperatures to dropByGraeme Murray:,  Mar |comments Sun lovers who have bathed in a mini-heatwave will be hit by a perishing cold snap as temperatures plummet.The final day to soak up sun rays is tomorrowbefore flurries of snow start in some parts of the UK Readings on temperature gauges have gone sky high in the last week with readings in around the C mark, but the mercury could fall to -C next week before snow flurries begin to settle. Snow will begin in the north on Wednesday and is expected to hit Scotland and the northern parts of England. Forecasters say around four inches is expected to lie in some areas.  The flurries will move to move into northern parts of England and could dump up to nine inches in the area, WX Charts says. In Wales, up to three inches will settle later in the week while Northern Ireland is not immune and will see some snow too. Large parts of the country will be hit by rain which will turn to sleet or snow as temperatures plummet. Tomorrow is set to be the last of the mini-heatwave, with temperatures hitting up to C at around pm. Met Office Chief Meteorologist Paul Gundersen told The Sun: “Although the UK has had a good deal of fine and settled March weather in recent days, a change is on the way from the middle of next week with colder air spreading down from the north and the increasing likelihood of rain for most areas. “On the hills in the north, there’s a chance of this falling as snow, although we’ll gain more certainty on that in the coming days. “With the influence of some unsettled weather, we’ll be seeing a marked drop in temperatures for most with colder air arriving from the north.The Mirror yesterday told of the coming cold snap, which will be shock to the system for those who had started to breakout their summer wardrobe.In some places there has been glorious temperatures of C and C highs, with seemingly endless sunshine. But a cold snap has been forecast by the BBC and WXCharts in Scotland, with snow expected for many areas. Flurries will arrive as early as Wednesday, but forecasters from The Met Office have said below average temperatures should come to an end later in April.BBC forecaster Darren Bett said: “There are some big changes in the weather pattern on the way but not just yet. Temperatures in rural areas will not be far away from freezing.  There maybe a few pockets of frost and fog to start the day across Scotland and Northern Ireland but away from Northern Isles there is set to be more sunshine for Scotland and Northern Ireland on Friday. Plenty of sunshine for England and Wales. Into next week though and this is where we see signicant changes not least because we are going to start to see a northerly wind moving down and that will really drop the temperatures, said Mr Bett. As the high recedes early next week we have got the chance of seeing some rain and then that northerly wind arrives it will be much colder by day and also by night.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeHeatwaveSnowWeather" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uk weather forecast temperatures halve
story: UK weather forecast: Temperatures to halve with snow coming before next weekendThe UK has enjoyed a recent string of warm and sunny days giving us  hope that summer weather is here to stay, but the temperatures are set to plunge across the countryThe above-average summery weather experienced around the UK this week is due to make way for more wintry conditions Image: Getty ImagesByAine Fox:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The UK will bask in balmy climes for another few days but temperatures are set to drop with some parts even likely to see snow before next weekend, forecasters say. Britain has enjoyed a recent string of warm and sunny days, giving us  hope that summer weather was here.In some places there has been glorious temperatures of C and C highs, with seemingly endless sunshine. But meteorologists say sunshine conditions will end this by Saturday or Sunday.People will get a taste of most of the seasons within the space of a few days, a Met Office forecaster has said, as above-average summery weather makes way for more wintry conditions.Clocks go forward overnight into Sunday, ushering in British Summer Time.  In Glasgow, the temperature is due to drop by half, from .C on Saturday to just C by Thursday. Hill snow is likely to affect some parts of Scotland on Tuesday night, and possibly across the Pennines and Welsh mountains by Wednesday, said forecaster Marco Petagna. He said: Weaposll get a taste of most of the seasons within the space of a few days. The UK was bathed in sunshine and blue skies again on Saturday, as a warm and dry spell continued. The mercury reached a high of .C in Porthmadog in Wales, and much of the country is likely to see temperatures in the mid to high teens again on Sunday.  Greater cloud cover across central and eastern England will mean temperatures are down a few degrees, Mr Petagna said. He added: But itaposs still pretty good for the time of year. The average at the end of March would usually only be C or C in the north and -C in the south. So itaposs still pretty good at the start of the week. He said there will be a more notable change from midweek, with Thursday looking likely to be a cold day for most with highs of between C and C. In the Met Officeaposs long-range forecast for the UK, which spans from March  to April , it expects showers to become more prominent, and even says some snow showers may hit northern areas. It reads: Becoming more unsettled to start the period, northern areas will see increasing amounts of cloud with a few showers. Breezy and feeling cooler than recently in the far north, with the potential for some snow showers at low levels. Temperatures near average in the south. Becoming less settled and colder thereafter, with a mixture of sunshine and showers for most, in addition to an increased likelihood of wintry hazards, particularly to the north. Nearer to the end of this period, temperatures are expected to gradually recover to average, though overnight frost remains possible during clearer spells. Showers or longer spells of rain look to become more frequent, with drier periods most likely to be short-lived. title: uni ignored after staff member
story: Uni ignored me after staff member made sexual remarks and did Nazi-style marchPHD student Rachael Hearns, who attends Manchester politan University, feels her claims about a member of staff making sexual remarks and doing a Nazi impression were ignoredThe -year-old was working part-time at the Movement Unit when the comments were made Image: Kenny Brown | Manchester Evening NewsBySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar A student who claims a member of staff made sexual comments and harassed her before doing a Nazi impression, says she was ignored after reporting it to her university. Rachael Hearns, a PhD student at Manchester politan University, says she was made to feel really uncomfortable after the member of staff made comments about her body.The -year-old has alleged the person pestered her about her mask before reenacting a Nazi-style march and making remarks about her body type while she worked at the uni in October last year, she told the Manchester Evening News.After immediately reporting the incident to the universityaposs HR department she was told they would be in touch, with policy stating a manger will arrange a formal meeting without reasonable delay.  However, the student was forced to send a follow up email and wasnapost given an official meeting until more than a month later on November , where she was allegedly told there was no CCTV of the incident and it was unlikely she could proceed with a complaint. She said: He introduced himself and I assumed he was probably staff but that wasnapost confirmed until I googled him afterwards. I was getting a general sense of what he needed. During that conversation he physically stopped me and askedI would take off my mask which I didnapost want to and am not allowed to. I politely said no I would rather not. At the time it was university policy...I also donapost have a problem with it. I told him that and it went into this whole conversation about whether I had considered standing up to that or arguing that and I said no because it hadn’t really bothered me.  He said he could tell I was athletic and he could tell that I was a runner. When he first said it I thought it might have been linked to the condition he was coming to talk about. But when I said no I used to be a swimmer he said aposoh yeah I can tell.apos Itaposs not the worst but it was just uncomfortable. As the conversation came to a close he went back to the whole covid conversation and continued to press that. I made it very clear that I wasnapost interested in continuing the conversation.  Then he did this Nazi-style march. He looked down, hunched his shoulders and did a little marching movement. Rachael, who moved from the US to Manchester in  and was working at the uni part-time, claims during the meeting she was told that due to university policy all other CCTV in the area had been wiped. She added: They told me I should prepare for the likely event I wouldnapost be able to move forward with my complaint because there wasnapost sufficient evidence to identy the inidual.  The HR adviser didnapost respond to my email. Instead, in a final meeting he expressed learning about a -day CCTV policy they were unaware of. I was told the CCTV gets wiped after  days. That is very publicly available on the university website and something everyone  seemed to know about. I would expect HR to know about this. By this point it was well over the  day time limit. He expressed his sympathies and regret for not knowing about this policy but he didnapost really show any emotion. He didnapost seem bothered. He told me that the department would use my case as a learning opportunity and that an inquiry into the state of the CCTV camera in the [clinic] would take place. The -year-old was told by the universityaposs HR advisor the member of staff the complaint was levelled against wouldnapost be made aware, which she described as pretty sh***y. Nobody even asked himhe was in [the uni] that day, she said.  I donapost knowthere is an established written record of this because an accusation was never formally brought forward. If it happens again and god forbid it’s worse I have no confidence it’s going to go any other way. That was my primary concern: it’s not about getting anyone in trouble or fired. I do think Iaposve exhausted everything. My bosses are all in complete support so I feel support internally. They are angry and frustrated as well. Policies and procedures are not being followed and I’m glad the only thing that happened was an annoyance for the day. Would this have been taken more seriouslythis was a more serious offence  Why can’t I get some security  I hate the fact heaposs going to get away with it, but I also hate the fact that I donapost feel safe. A Manchester politan University spokesman said: We are sorry that Miss Hearn feels that the investigation process has not been handled correctly. We continue to speak with Miss Hearn about her concerns and we will ensure that she can feel safe and supported when at the University. title: woman widowed 25 after childhood
story: Woman widowed at  after childhood sweetheart dies weeks after dream weddingDevastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham, , lost her beloved husband Simon, , after he suffered multiple organ failure - seven weeks after their dream weddingDevastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham lost husband Simon, , on February  Image: Lucy Hesford-BuckinghamByFfion Lewis:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA woman has been widowed at  after her childhood sweetheart died seven weeks after their dream wedding. Devastated Lucy Hesford-Buckingham lost husband Simon, , on February . Simon had been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis four years ago and was admitted to intensive care just three weeks after their special day with multiple organ failure.Lucy described Simon as the most giving and caring person Iaposve ever met, WalesOnline reports. The couple met when Lucy was  and Simon . They had remained together ever since. Simonaposs condition deteriorated after a change in medication last year and he spent time in and out of hospital in the last months of his le. The pair were due to marry in December  but postponed the wedding due to Simonaposs illness. I think we always knew it would have an impact on his le, but we didnapost know it would take his le, said Lucy.  Simonaposs liver stopped working due to his condition which in turn had an impact on the rest of his organs. Lucy said that at first it appeared as though his condition was improving. She said: In the coma they brought him off everything to try and wake him up naturally. And he did start to wake up. I was sitting there and he wasnapost able to talk because he had a pipe in his mouth but he was able to shake his head and, you know, we were having quite coherent conversations. But then it all just deteriorated within the space of two days. I have to say they were amazing. All the nurses and the consultants were absolutely amazing to him I canapost fault them. They all came to the funeral as well which was lovely.Until October Simon was coping with his condition well. He was absolutely fine, Lucy said. He was perfect. We were going to the gym all the time. He was the fit one out of the two of us. But then they tried dferent medication - added some more in to seeit would give a good influence - and it all went downhill. The pair, who lived in Crynant, Dulais Valley, married on January  in Craig-y-Nos Castle in what Lucy described as the perfect day. She said that although Simon was ill on the day, it was important for him that they married. It was so nice, it was amazing, said Lucy. Simon was ill on the day and he was kind of resting and to be fair his best man was looking after him all day. But he was there for all the most important bits, he was there for the majority of the time. He was so chuffed that we did it. And I think he would have tried to get well for the first time to have it because he was just so adamant that we were going to get married.  I think part of you will always think aposthey mustaposve known they were going to pass awayapos, so part of me thinks he knew and thataposs why he wanted to get married but you never know do you. She said: When everyone puts their relationship on social media they try to portray it as perfect, but I never felt like I needed to do that because I knew what we had was perfect. So many people came up to me and said that we were more than a couple, we were perfect for each other. Simon was the most giving person you would ever meet. He was so caring. Everyone gravitated towards him because he was so calm. He was a therapist and he had this craft where he could sit there with you, rearrange your thoughts, and get you a better view on le in minutes. It was immaculate the way he would do it.  Lucy said the pair were inseparable and had only spent the evening before the wedding apart in the last six months of his le. She said: I donapost know what Iaposm doing. Itaposs been a month and still day to day I couldnapost tell you what Iaposve done. I think I am going through trauma just as much now as I was then. The way my brain is coping with it is to zone out. Obviously because I was in hospital with him the flashbacks I am having are horric. As soon as it happens I feel like I zone out for what feels like ages.  If someone had said to me when I was put on this world, aposdo you want nine years of perfection with a soul mate or  years of a mundane relationship with someone who fits the billapos I would have picked Simon every time. Right now Iaposm trying to focus on the positive part of it but I know that is going to come crashing down. There is a degree of numbness at the moment. Lucy said they used to enjoy creating YouTube videos and content together and that it is doing nothing together that she will miss the most. We just loved being together. I could go through all the memories of all the things were did together, but the things I think of is just sitting in the house watching TV. I donapost feel like heaposs gone. I know his body is not here but I still feel him around me all the time. Lucy has now started a charity in memory of Simon who had recently completed a degree that would allow him to be a counsellor. She said that Simon was passionate about providing young people who are autistic and neuroergent with accessible therapy, something he struggled to find. Simon worked alongside the Kimel foundation and had undertaken a course with them and they were later going to take him on as a counsellor. Lucy said: Simon just wanted to help people. He said aposwhen I graduate I donapost want to work for money, I feel like Iaposve taken money for something I could do for freeapos. He just wanted to help and would give anything to help someone.Lucy and Simonaposs family would gratefully receive donations in his memory to the Kimel Foundation who will be part of the charity in memory of Simon.
