title: first parasport festival a success
story: The inaugural Scottish Disability Sport Shetland Parasport Festival took place yesterdayin Clickimin Leisure Centre with competitors taking part in numerous sports.Organised by Ability Shetland the festival is designed to introduce students from mainstream schools with a physical, visual or hearing impairment to try new activities via taster events.It has been identied that these iniduals are signicantly under-represented when it comes to participating in weekly sport or physical activity.Taster events that participants could try included rugby, wheelchair basketball, Boccia and kayaking.A person has been transferred to hospital after being medically evacuated from an offshore facility by the coast guard#s Rescue  helicopter. title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220325newsrecommendation for post primary pupils to wear facemasks to be scrapped after easter
story: It will no longer be recommended that post-primary pupils wear a face covering in corridors or confined communal areas following the Easter break. This will result in post-primary pupils no longer being recommended to wear a face covering on school premises. The news was confirmed by Education Minister Michelle McIlveen.She said, As was the case with the change relating to the use of face coverings in classrooms, this further change takes place in the context of a broadly improving epidemiological landscape in schools. Nonetheless, COVID continues to circulate in our communities and in our schools and we should continue to reduce the risks of COVID in our schools through the range of other mitigating measures that remain in place to protect all pupils and staff.  It is for this reason thatany inidual wishes to continue to use a face covering anywhere at school, I would encourage them to do so. At this point pupils will still be recommended to wear a face covering when using public or school transport. This position will be kept under review.  A guidance note will issue to schools on this issue later today and my Department’s COVID guidance will be updated to reflect this position.

title: gallaher trust seeks outside the box ideas
story: THE Gallaher Trust is searching for social enterprises, charities and ‘those who can think outside the box’ to help make a dference to the Ballymena community. The Trust has announced that funding applications for delivery partners have opened for . One of those ‘outside the box’ ideas was the creation of the Northern Ireland Hospitality School, which allowed three local hoteliers to come together under the umbrella of a not-for-profit organisation to create courses and programmes for the Ballymena hospitality sector.The Northern Ireland Hospitality School, as a delivery partner, was launched last year in conjunction with Northern Regional College . The Trust, over the next three years, has committed almost pound,, offering students a chance to expand their skills and gain guaranteed employment with one of three local hotels – the Tullyglass House Hotel, the Adair Arms and the Galgorm Golf Resort and Spa. Since its launch, a total of  students have completed the Level  Professional Bartending course and have gone on to secure full-time employment. Joel Johnston, a former student of the Northern Ireland Hospitality School, who now works at Gillies Grill as part of the Galgorm Golf Resort and Spa in Ballymena, has been reflecting on his experience.“I’m really glad that the Northern Ireland Hospitality School was able to become a delivery partner with The Gallaher Trust,” Joel said. “Completing the Level  Professional Bartending course has made such a positive impact on my le I was able to develop my skills and now I’m working in a field that I’m truly passionate about.“I have always wanted to work within the hospitality industry and when I saw that a Hospitality School had been launched in Ballymena, I couldn’t wait to apply. “The Professional Bartending course has given me a great launchpad into my career. Working within hospitality can be tough, but the course has equipped me with all the skills necessary to thrive.“I am an employee at Gillies Grill and I’m really enjoying it. The Hospitality School has made such a dference to my le and I’m not sureI would be in this position without it. Any eligible organisation that requires funding and support should definitely apply to become a delivery partner with The Gallaher Trust. Their support helps to get projects off the ground which can make a big impact on the people of Ballymena – just like the Hospitality School.”Elsewhere, Ian Paisley MP, Chairman of The Gallaher Trust says he’s delighted with the success of the Hospitality School thus far and is speaking out to encourage other eligible organisations to apply for funding.“On behalf of The Gallaher Trust, we are so proud that the Hospitality School is achieving its purpose of developing skills and creating jobs for adults within the Ballymena community,” Ian commented.“Our mission at the Trust is to work alongside delivery partners that are aiming to make a real dference in peoples’ lives by creating jobs, developing skills and helping disadvantaged adults.“Delivery partner applications are now open and to be eligible, you must be a charity, a not-for-profit based organisation or a social enterprise, that can make an impact on the greater Ballymena area.“I would strongly urge any organisation that is eligible, to apply for funding today. We have seen from the likes of the Hospitality School, that it could make a massive dference to your project and ultimately the people of Ballymena, which is our clear purpose.”For more information about becoming a delivery partner, visit the Contact Us section of The Gallaher Trust’s website: https:thegallahertrust.org contact-us . Applications for funding and eligibility guidance can also be downloaded from the website.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327news200 000 pledged to support agricultural shows
story: Outgoing AgricultureMinister Edwin Pootshas announced a pound, package of support for Northern Ireland’s agricultural shows following the Covid- pandemic. Announcing the bounce back support scheme, Mr Poots said: “Many businesses and sectors were adversely affected by the Covid- pandemic, and our agricultural shows were not immune to these effects, with all shows cancelled in  and only a few being able to take place in . This resulted in shows losing the opportunity to raise vital funds that would help prepare for the  season. “Shows play a vital role in showcasing our excellent agri-food produce and supporting our rural communities, as well as boosting our economy and the additional tourism opportunities. These shows are predominately run by many volunteers who give of their free time and I would like to extend my thanks to them for all of their hard work. “Pre-pandemic agricultural shows attracted more than , visitors. It is essential therefore that NI shows have the opportunity to run a full schedule this year to promote and facilitate future economic growth for agri-food businesses and I am pleased that I can support their efforts through the provision of the pound, bounce back support scheme I’ve announced today, which will allow each show to claim up to a maximum of poundk for new or increased costs. “Departmental officials will contact shows directly in the next few weeks to assist them in availing of my support scheme.” Looking to the future, Mr Poots has announced plans for an independent review of local agricultural shows, which will explore the potential for longer term support options and help shows remain sustainable in the years ahead. He added: “Although I am providing support to our local shows this year, I am of the view that Government departments and local councils should consider options for longer term support. “I am therefore announcing plans for an independent review to commence in the next month or two which will aim to explore future support options and guide future policy, in addition to identying new and innovative methods which would be utilised by local shows to help safeguard their future.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220327newshargey tackles digital exclusion through provision of free broadband
story: Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey has announced the provision of free broadband for those facing digital exclusion as a barrier to work. The broadband support package will be available to eligible jobseekers through the Department for Communities’ Adviser Discretion Fund, a grant fund available to help remove barriers to employment that prevent people moving towards and into employment Minister Hargey said: “Digital exclusion has been one of the inequalities thrown into sharper focus by the Covid- pandemic. “More than ever, employers are posting vacancies online, with many having moved to online interviewing and more positions requiring people to work from home. “Therefore, not having access to broadband can be a signicant barrier to searching for, or moving into, employment. “I am tackling this by providing free broadband support which will provide broadband for eligible jobseekers who do not currently have the service.” Support for broadband through the Adviser Discretion Fund is available for a period of six months. The Fund can provide a non-repayable grant of up to pound,, in a  month period, to remove barriers to employment. The Minister continued: “The success of the Adviser Discretion Fund in helping remove barriers to employment has already been seen throughout the year, particularly in the uptake of upfront childcare costs, which I made available last October. “I am delighted that we have already helped around  parents with average upfront childcare costs of approximately pound. “This additional scheme will help remove similar barriers to employment for those facing digital exclusion due to a lack of broadband service.”

Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Just half of Belfast residents feel city is safe after dark, council survey findsExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJust half of Belfast residents have said they feel safe in the city centre after dark.Christina Black FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJust half of Belfast residents have said they feel safe in the city centre after dark.Andrew MaddenTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA new survey of Belfast residents has found % are satisfied with the city as a place to live —but just half said they felt safe in the centre after dark.Every two years, Belfast City Council commissions consultants to carry out a survey of residents to gauge satisfaction with their local authority and le in the city.The survey is normally carried out face-to-face, although this year’s was conducted by phone due to Covid restrictions. A total of , people were interviewed between November  and December , using quotas to ensure those completing the survey were representative of the population. A Belfast City Councilbriefing paper for members of the authority’s Strategic Policy and Resources Committee reads: “On the whole, the results for  are positive. “In , satisfaction with council and le in Belfast dipped, a trend replicated across the rest of the UK.“This year, our results have improved on  and are now generally on a par, and in some places better than the  results. “For most of the council indicators we have reversed the downward trend in satisfaction and approval ratings, whereas this has continued in English council areas.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “The committee is asked to note that overall satisfaction with Belfast and local area remains lower than in  , though still higher when compared to other local authorities.“Some data has fallen, such as views on whether all people can lead healthy lives or live le to the full, whether they feel listened to and whether they feel safe in the city centre at night. “This data will be used to inform improvement activities of council and the Belfast Agenda.”Looking at the results of the survey, % of respondents were satisfied with Belfast as a place to live, while % felt the city was a good place to visit, and % said Belfast residents are friendly, caring and compassionate.Some % of those surveyed said Belfast has good infrastructure, while % felt the city centre was vibrant, attractive and with lots going on.In terms of the more negative responses, % said they would not agree that Belfast is an environmentally-friendly city, and % disagreed with the statement that everyone in Belfast experiences good health and wellbeing.Worryingly, just over half of those surveyedsaid they felt safe in the city centre after dark.Back in October last year, Sinn Fein councillor Christina Black requested the council to begin work on a new strategy of city centre safety for women.“We all know the city centre has changed during, and emerging out of, lockdown, and with that perceptions of safety. “The experience of safety for women has to some degree altered, but it is very dficult to get an accurate benchmark,” she said during a meeting of BCC’s People and Communities Committee.”And she added: “Some incidents are not being picked up because of non-reporting, and that can be due to a lack of clarity about who to report an incident to, or whether it will be deemed serious enough, orit will actually be listened to.“But issues of street public harassment are happening, so what can we be doing to change attitudes and enhance city safety  “This request is not about criminalising or demonising, it is about exploring additional avenues for women to report issues that have concerned them.”Related topicsBelfast City CouncilSinn FéinMore On Belfast City Council PremiumJon TongeOpinionBurnham and Rotheram title: p and o ferries rivals set to meet with officials after mass sacking of staff
story: FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBy Alan Jones and Sam Blewett, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBosses from two of PO Ferries’ rivals are due to meet with Government officials to discuss the fallout from the firm’s widely-criticised move to sack  staff.The Department for Transporthas invited DFDS and Stena Lines for talks on Monday, amid concerns over chaos at ports during the Easter holidays.The department confirmed the meeting is taking place, but declined to comment on the topics for discussion.But a spokesman said: “Ministers are working to understand how we can ensure the continuation of services in collaboration with other operators, including DFDS and Stena.”Prime Minister Boris Johnson backed Transport Secretary Grant Shapps’ call for PO boss Peter Hebblethwaite to quit over the mass sacking of the hundreds of workers without notice in March , with replacements being paid the minimum wage.The meeting is set to come after the PA news agency learned PO Ferries conducted a study last year into options to sustain the company which calculated it would cost £ million to keep the business going while consulting with staff over job losses.It decided against a full staff consultation over its plans to cut almost  jobs, a move which has attracted a huge backlash from unions and politicians.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up A company source said the study calculated it would cost £ million to keep the business going through a consultation period of at least three months, adding there was no guarantee of recovery.Months of consultations would have undermined the business, caused disruption which would have led to customers leaving to competitors, dealing a “fatal blow” to PO, the source told PA."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming dcf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming dcf .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "People take part in a demonstration against the dismissal of PandO workers PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePeople take part in a demonstration against the dismissal of PandO workers PO believes it has safeguarded the long-term future of the company and the livelihoods of , employees.A PO spokesperson said: “Over % of seafarers affected are in discussions to progress with the severance offers.“We are sorry to the people affected and their families for the impact it’s had on them. They’ve lost their jobs and there is anger and shock, which we completely understand.“We needed fundamental change to make the business viable. This was an incredibly dficult decision that we wrestled with but once we knew it was the only way to save the business, we had to act.“All other routes led to the loss of , jobs and the closure of PO Ferries.“In making this hard choice we have guaranteed the future viability of PO Ferries and secured Britain’s trading capacity.“We are committed to ensuring the continued and ongoing support for all those former and current employees affected.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming af .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming af .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming af .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming af .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_abcc--ffb-cd-bfccf_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Peter Hebblethwaite, chief executive of PandO Ferries PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePeter Hebblethwaite, chief executive of PandO Ferries The company said the settlement with its workers is believed to be the largest compensation package in the British Marine Sector.A total of  employees are receiving more than £, and in some cases are over £,, said PO.The total value of the financial settlement is over £ million.Protests were held in Liverpool, Hull and Dover on Saturday and more are planned in the coming days.The Rail, Maritime and Transport and Nautilus International unions are urging the company to reverse the sackings and for the Government to take action against PO.A ship operated by the ferry firm was detained for being “unfit to sail” on Friday.The European Causeway vessel was held at the port of Larne in Northern Ireland due to “failures on crew familiarisation, vessel documentation and crew training”, the Maritime and Coastguard Agencysaid.Mr Hebblethwaite admitted to MPs that the firm broke the law by not consulting over the sackings.Mick Lynch, general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union, said: “The campaign to get the workers back on the ships, operating these crucial ferry links safely goes on and the company need to face up to the hard facts and take responsibility for their grotesque actions.”Most ReadDodgy east Belfast botox beautician must pay title: psni in search for teenager believed to have attempted very disturbing burglary spree in bangor
story: Image of the Old Windmill Road in Crawfordsburn. Credit: Google Maps FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueImage of the Old Windmill Road in Crawfordsburn. Credit: Google MapsNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailPolice are looking for a young man believed to be solely responsible for five reported incidents of possible burglary in Bangor on Saturday night, with one car having items stolen from within it.Detectives said they are investigating a number of reported incidents which occurred in the Old Windmill Road area of Crawfordsburn in the Co Down region.Detective Sergeant Shivers said: “In total we have been informed of five incidents at properties in the area on Saturday evening involving, we believe, the same male.It was reported that the male entered three of the properties only to be disturbed by residents on each occasion forcing him to flee. In a fourth property, the male has entered a house, taken keys to a car parked outside and attempted to drive it away, but was unable to do so.Read MoreBlack Mercedes and sum of money among items stolen in ‘creeper style’ east Belfast burglaryA further report was then received on Sunday morning that a car which had been parked in the Old Windmill Road area had been entered with a number of items stolen from inside.“This is a very disturbing series of incidents for the residents affected and they have, understandably, been left badly shaken as a result. A description of the male involved is that he was aged in his late teens, had short ginger hair and was wearing a dark coloured hooded top and light grey trousers.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “I am appealing to anyone who was in the area and noticed any suspicious activity on Saturday evening or anyone who may have captured dash-cam footage from the area which could assist us with our enquiries to call detectives in Bangor on the non-emergency number , quoting reference number    , or submit a report online using our non-emergency reporting form via http:www.psni.police.uk makeareport .You can also contact Crimestoppers anonymously on    or online at http:crimestoppers-uk.org .”Most ReadDodgy east Belfast botox beautician must pay back £kFormer Northern Ireland Tory on upskirting and indecent child title: rubbish piles pictured on county antrim road while council bin collection workers near end of week long strike
story: Rubbish piled beside a bin on the A carriageway outside Larne on March th,  Kevin Scott   Belfast Rubbish piled beside a bin on the A carriageway outside LarneKevin Scott   Belfast "data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland eab .ece AUTOCROP w A%carriageway w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland eab .ece AUTOCROP w A%carriageway w" data-sizes"auto"  "Rubbish piled beside a bin on the A carriageway outside Larne on March th,  Kevin Scott   Belfast "data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland af .ece AUTOCROP w A%carriageway w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland af .ece AUTOCROP w A%carriageway w" data-sizes"auto"  "Rubbish piled beside a bin on the A carriageway outside Larne. Kevin Scott   Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRubbish piled beside a bin on the A carriageway outside Larne on March th,  Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailLarge numbers of bin bags filled to their brims have been pictured lining the side of a road in County Antrim.The rubbish piles were seen placed beside a public bin alongside the A carriageway outside Larne on Sunday afternoon the final day of planned strike action by council workers, education staff and Housing Executive employees in Northern Ireland.The litter was collected and bagged by volunteers from a local environmental group, Eco Rangers NI, “as part of an ongoing experiment to highlight the blight of rural litter”, according to one resident.The group has been working to clean up local public areas for the last two years, and members usually leave the bags at the side of the road to be collected by the council. Founder of the group, Abe Agnew, said This is a joint exercise by Live Here Love Here [a charitable community organisation], Mid and East Antrim Council, and carried out by the Eco Rangers. Council staff have been collecting hundreds of these blue bags for the last two years. We hope the workers will get a decent wage settlement.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreSam McBride:OpinionDUP’s future looks increasingly grim… now party must hope damage it has done to the union is not irreparableNorthern Ireland traffic alerts: North Belfast road closed after wall collapsesAccording to trade union Unite, striking council workers have watched their pay “stagnate over the last decade meaning real terms falls in their standards of living of % over the period”.A ballot by Unite the Union took place across all  local authority members here, with bin collections in Mid and East Antrim Borough Council – which Larne falls under – and Derry and Strabane District Council affected the most.The industrial action began on Monday, March  and was set to finish yesterday.In addition to school transport services and bin collections, street cleansing, recycling centres and leisure centres were also hit hard.A statement issued by Mid and East Antrim Borough Council on social media said: “We’re working hard to minimise the impact caused by this industrial action, with the majority of services expected to operate as normal, except for bin collections, street cleansing, recycling centres and leisure centres which are likely to be impacted most.“We will update our social channels and website to advise of any disruptions.”Read MoreBin collections affected across Northern Ireland Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsNorthern Ireland Assembly election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumUnionism remains as ided in  as it was in , now it might be too late to do things dferentlyAlex KaneFty years on from the closing of Northern Ireland’s House of Commons and the problems look much the same for unionism, writes Alex KaneExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClosePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontThe Prime Minister Brian Faulkner with members of his cabinet in . Credit: Charles CockcroftStormont. Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePicture taken during the last sitting NI House of Commons. Faulkner and other Cabinet ministers address a mass rally of Vanguard supporters from the balcony of StormontMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAt .pm, on March , , Northern Ireland’s House of Commons adjourned. It was never to meet again. Two days later the NI Temporary Provisions Act became law, introducing direct rule, ending  years of unionist government, bringing devolution to a stop and shutting down NI’s Parliament. It was the biggest crisis for unionism since the  Home Rule Bill.At lunchtime on March , Brian Faulkner, destined to be NI’s last Prime Minister, led his Cabinet onto the balcony to address the enormous crowdwhich had gathered in the grounds. He had only a loudspeaker.“People of Ulster, I am speaking to you still as Prime Minister of Northern Ireland. I want to say, not just on my own behalf, but on behalf of every one of my colleagues in the Government and the Parliamentary Party here at Stormont, that we understand absolutely the feelings which have persuaded you to come out to Parliament Buildings today… we share the resentment that you feel. We have tremendous power.“Our power is the power of our numbers our power is the justice of our cause our power is the responsibility of our conduct. Let us never play the game of the murderers of the IRA. Let us show the world that, so far as we are concerned, violence and intimidation are out. British we are and British we remain!”The previous day Faulkner had addressed an emergency meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council, informing it that his government had lost confidence in Edward Heath’s administration.By his own admission it was an angry meeting seething at what was regarded as a betrayal and surrender to unionism’s enemies. But he also warned them to shun violent responses and rely, instead, on the ‘Unionist veto’ which lay in the strength of their numbers.Exactly  years later, on Monday March , the present Assembly will be dissolved in preparation for an election on May . There are many within the unionist community who believe that, like its predecessor on March , , this institution will not meet again.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Political unionism is again seething with anger, believing that another Conservative government has betrayed it and rolled over to the demands of those who want Northern Ireland removed from the United Kingdom. Indeed, they would argue that the process of removal has been advanced by a protocol which traps Northern Ireland in some sort of constitutional halfway house between Great Britain, the Republic of Ireland and the European Union.When Brian Faulkner spoke of unionism relying on the strength of its numbers it was at a time when the combined pro-Union vote hovered around two-thirds of the overall vote.At the election for the first post-NI Parliament Assembly, in June , the pro-Union votewas %. In the  Assembly election that votehad reduced to .%.That election also saw unionism reduced to a minority within an NI Parliament and Assembly: and there is now a possibility, come May , that unionism won’t even have the numbers to qualy for the position of First Minister.And yet unionism remains as ided now as it was back in . The narrowing of the demographic gap between unionism and nationalism, along with an ongoing reluctance by successive British governments to be seen to be what might be described as pro-active on behalf of unionism, hasn’t pushed it in the direction of prioritising a coherent, collective, long-term strategy for survival.Even the thundering hammer-blows rained down on the DUP by Boris Johnson continue to be greeted with fairly mild responses from the party leadership.Speaking on Monday evening Jeffrey Donaldson acknowledged the problem: “It’s not a question of throwing the DUP under the bus. The Prime Minister threw Northern Ireland under the bus and the harm that this protocol has done to Northern Ireland is, I think, something the Prime Minister now recognises. But we need him to do something about it.”The problem, of course, is that Donaldson has been saying this since September last yearand Johnson has done nothing. He’ll continue to do nothing until May : and, in all likelihood, will do nothing after that, either.In March  Brian Faulkner and the UUP decided to risk the collapse of the NI Parliament rather than allow control of security to pass from the NI government to Westminster.A few days before Stormont was prorogued Faulkner had written to Edward Heath: ‘We wish to point out with a sense of the heavy responsibility involved that the imposition of this proposal, involving as it will the resignation of the Government of Northern Ireland as a whole, may have the gravest consequences, the full extent of which cannot now be foreseen.’We now know the primary consequence of the resignation and subsequent prorogation: the end of majority rule, the introduction of mandatory power-sharingand the sapping of unionist confidence that their future position within the United Kingdom was, to all intents and purposes, secure.What Faulkner did — although I fully understand why he had to do it — was hand over the political negotiating process to a British government which was determined to build an entirely dferent relationship with its Irish counterpart.In his biography, Memoirs of a Statesman , Faulkner hinted at regrets: “... when unionists of vision tried to stimulate new thinking and broaden the appeal of unionism in the s s I did not come out and support them. I did not think they were achieving anything useful...but we should have spent more time watering the roots of tolerance.“We did not take the initiative in reforming our society until events forced change on us. By  we were reacting to events rather than controlling them and one was always conscious of running very fast merely to make up lost ground.’Since then, a number of other unionist loyalist leaders have voiced fairly similar regrets. Sometimes about their own personal lack of foresight and sometimes about opportunities which unionism may have missed over the decades.Yet as Faulkner noted, there was always a sense that unionism was a few steps behind the thinking of others when it came to mapping out Northern Ireland’s post- future. Or, as former UUP leader Reg Empey put it, “every time unionism walks from the table it inevitably and iniably s to another table with a weaker hand”.In the early s a Minister of State based in the NIO told me: “The problem with unionism — and it’s a particular problem for those outside Northern Ireland who try to understand it — is that there are far too many ieties. They spend as much time complaining about their unionist rivals as they do complaining about their more specic political and constitutional opponents.”From until the collapse of Stormont in  the isions could mostly be controlled by the mantra — ‘United we stand. Divided we fall.’ But once the fall came there was nothing to hold unionism together and it splintered and continues to splinter.Faulkner and power-sharing were destroyed by the United Ulster Unionist Council in . Shortly afterwards the ious members of the UUUC — who couldn’t come up with an agreed alternative to the Sunningdale deal — turned on themselves.The UUP descended into civil war between -. The loyalist paramilitary groups, essential to the ‘selling’ of the Good Friday Agreement, have now withdrawn support for it. The DUP has had a horrible  months and is still beset with internal dficulties.A growing element of younger loyalism is pushing its anti-protocol campaigning towards prioritising the final collapse of the GFA institutions. And Jeffrey Donaldson and Jim Allisterhave laid down pre-election preconditions on both the protocol and the eventuality of a Sinn Fein First Minister.Change a few names and organisations and we could be talking about that period from March  to May  — when unionism and loyalism were struggling to find a route map from the crisis forced on them by widespread political societal instability and British governments which were determined to impose change upon them.But here’s the reality:the strategies and policies adopted by unionists didn’t work back then, why does anyone think terribly similar strategies and policies would work today: particularly when the constitutional crisis is worse now than then and the shadow of a border poll is hanging over every aspect of the coming election.A British state paper released in  had this assessment of the  Assembly election: ‘Mr Faulkner’s position is undoubtedly dficult. He will have less than half of the Protestant vote behind him, as Dr Paisley and others will no doubt vocerously remind him,and when he makes an effort to work the new system.“It was always to be anticipated that the Protestant vote would be fragmented… but the outcome has left the potential accepters weaker and the ‘wreckers’ stronger than expected.’Something very similar happened to David Trimble in , allowing his internal and external opponents to destroy him. Might the same thing be about to happen to Jeffrey Donaldson  Between  and  the DUP vote represented a majority of unionist votes cast — but even then, the party had to temper a lot of decisions and steer away from potential compromises and concessions. If the DUP doesn’t represent the majority of unionist votes cast and seats won in the Assembly on May  it will make it very dficult for Donaldson to reboot the executive.We seem to be on ‘the more things change, the more they stay the same’ territory for unionism. Again. But there is one dference. I was in that crowd in the grounds of Stormont on March , , a few months short of my th birthday.I recognised the scale of the shock: but I also recognised something , a new opportunity for unionism to do things dferently. My big fear today — and I’m very pessimistic, by the way, about a rebooted Assembly— is that unionism may have left it too late to do things dferently.Related topicsIRAAlliance PartyBoris JohnsonSir
